query: If $p(t)$ and $q(t)$ are both seventh-degree polynomials in $t$, what is the degree of $p(t)\cdot q(t)$?
ground_truth: The $t^7$ terms multiply to a $t^{14}$ term.  All the other terms multiply to terms of lesser degree, so the degree of the product of polynomials is $\boxed{14}$.
answers_list:
[reasoning process] To determine the degree of the product of two polynomials, we need to know the degrees of each polynomial involved. A polynomial's degree is defined as the highest power of the variable in its expression. In this case, both \( p(t) \) and \( q(t) \) are seventh-degree polynomials, meaning that the highest power of \( t \) in both polynomials is 7. 

When multiplying two polynomials, the degree of the resulting polynomial is equal to the sum of the degrees of the individual polynomials. Thus, if \( \text{deg}(p(t)) = 7 \) and \( \text{deg}(q(t)) = 7 \), we can use the formula:

\[
\text{deg}(p(t) \cdot q(t)) = \text{deg}(p(t)) + \text{deg}(q(t)) = 7 + 7 = 14.
\]

[Verification] To ensure the correctness of this calculation, we can consider an example. Let:

\[
p(t) = t^7 + a_6t^6 + \ldots + a_0
\]
\[
q(t) = t^7 + b_6t^6 + \ldots + b_0
\]

The product \( p(t) \cdot q(t) \) will have the leading term formed by multiplying the leading terms of \( p(t) \) and \( q(t) \). The leading term will be \( t^7 \cdot t^7 = t^{14} \), which indicates that the highest degree term in the product is \( t^{14} \) and confirms that:

\[
\text{deg}(p(t) \cdot q(t)) = 14.
\]

Thus, the degree calculation holds true through both mathematical reasoning and verification through an example.

[Final Answer] The answer is 14 \n#### 14
